entry.title: Sunrise Stepanakert festival kicks off in Armenia and Artsakh

media:group.media:title: Sunrise Stepanakert festival kicks off in Armenia and Artsakh
media:group.media:description:
Itâ€™s the opening event of this yearâ€™s Sunrise Stepanakert, the first multimedia art festival in Artsakh. Traditionally, Sunrise Stepanakert did take place in Stepanakert, but Azerbiajanâ€™s blockade of the region has forced the organizers towards new solutions. Now in its third year, the program will span different cities in Armenia in addition to Stepanakert.
The festival includes masterclasses and film screenings, and will also feature a pop-up shop at NPAK, open 12:00 - 9:00 PM for the duration of the festival, full of a curated selection of products made by independent Armenian artists, designers, and creators.

entry.title: How Is Nagorno-Karabakh Handling Its Deepening Energy Crisis?

media:group.media:title: How Is Nagorno-Karabakh Handling Its Deepening Energy Crisis?
media:group.media:description:
For over six months, Nagorno-Karabakh has been relying on its internal energy supply due to Azerbaijanâ€™s blockade of the region. Now, this supply is growing increasingly scarce, deepening the existing energy crisis in the region. Although Stepanakertâ€™s authorities have instituted a strict energy conservation policy to mitigate the crisis, they continue to explore alternative energy sources and prepare for the worst.

entry.title: â€œWe are the leaders of changeâ€, Mariam Torosyan

media:group.media:title: â€œWe are the leaders of changeâ€, Mariam Torosyan
media:group.media:description:
Mariam Torosyan sits down with Lara Tcholakian to share her thoughts about the key issues related to gender and women in Armenian society today, including violence, harassment, and bullying. She shares her thoughts on what a successful leader should incorporate, and the values needed to lead mindfully, such as self-awareness, authenticity, and value-based leadership. They discuss Mariam's childhood growing up after the fall of the Soviet Union, her historical background and her connection with her roots, including her late maternal grandfather and role model, Dr. Eduard Baghdasaryan. Finally, Torosyan shares her thoughts on how she sees the future of Armenia, the value of repatriates in increasing the knowledgebase of the country, and the crucial role of new changemakers to lead a healthy society.
About Mariam Torosyan Mariam Torosyan is the co-founder and the Chief Executive Officer of the Impact Innovations Institute and Safe YOU mobile application and web platform intended to fight gender-based violence with over 28,000 users. Torosyan is a fellow with the Cartier Womenâ€™s Initiative, and has been recognized as European Young Innovator (WSA) and Young Transatlantic Innovation Leader. She has taken part in Google for Startups, UNDP Boost for Women Innovators, and the UNFPA Innovation Challenge. Torosyan has a background in Human Rights and Healthcare Law and is pursuing doctoral research in Law and Anthropology. She is also a lecturer of Healthcare Law at the Yerevan State Medical University.
Program overview In a new open setting, Lara deconstructs inherited cultural and historical narratives, memories, life lessons and experiences from change catalysts. Her guests reflect on the stories, people, events and mindsets that have shaped their professional and personal lives, enabling them to create a more mindful life.

entry.title: Trial of abducted Armenian servicemen begins in Azerbaijan

They face charges of illegally crossing the Armenia-Azerbaijan border. ğŸ“Armen Grigoryan, the head of Armeniaâ€™s Security Council, is traveling to Washington for meetings with high-level U.S. officials, days after the latest round of Armenia-Azerbaijan talks ended.

entry.title: â€œYoung Armenians need to see a future, in order to pursue a career in the sciencesâ€

media:group.media:title: â€œYoung Armenians need to see a future, in order to pursue a career in the sciencesâ€
media:group.media:description:
Vahe Petrosian is a professor of physics and applied physics at Stanford University. He is in Armenia to attend the Armenian Society of Fellows conference which works to advance higher education and research in the country. Professor Petrosian discusses why youth interest is so important for a strong science sector, as well as why clear career paths must be available in order for young Armenians to pursue a career in the sector. He also speaks about the growing presence of Armenians in science faculties, research centers and institutions around the world.

entry.title: Water outages and gas deficits are the new normal in Gishi, Artsakh

media:group.media:title: Water outages and gas deficits are the new normal in Gishi, Artsakh
media:group.media:description:
The population of Artsakh has been subjected to a blockade for over half a year now. Azerbaijan's closure of the Lachin corridor has left the region without access to Armenia or to the rest of the world. During this time, CivilNet continues to visit different villages in Artsakh to understand first-hand how the people have been impacted by the blockade.
This time, we are in Gishi Village in Artsahkhâ€™s Martuni Region to talk to residents about the direct effect that the blockade has had on them.
